Climate Requirements: Tropical to subtropical; thrives in rainforests, disturbed forests, and open grasslands; altitude 50–1050 m
Soil Type: Prefers well-drained loamy to sandy soil; tolerant to limestone
Water Needs: Moderate; grows in semi-moist to dry habitats
Traditional Uses: Bark rich in saponins; used in India as natural shampoo and hair conditioner; valued in Ayurveda for promoting scalp health and hair strength

Climate Requirements: Prefers warm tropical climates; found in brackish and saline marshes within mangrove forests; occasional in freshwater swamps; cannot tolerate prolonged flooding
Soil Type: Moist, saline, or brackish soils; tolerates high salinity in sporophyte stage but not in gametophyte
Sun Light Needs: Partial to full sunlight; thrives on landward edge of mangroves
Water Needs: Moderate; adapted to semi-aquatic marshes but not deep water
Growth Rate: Moderate; grows up to 3 feet tall; perennial
Ecological Role: Among the first colonizers on mangrove edges; provides shade for young mangrove trees; stabilizes soil; dense thickets offer habitat and nesting grounds for birds (e.g., Purple Heron); considered a weed when it dominates cleared mangrove areas
Traditional Uses: Rhizomes pounded into paste for wounds; leaves used to stop bleeding; methanolic extract studied for selective cytotoxic activity against cancerous cells (e.g., HeLa); young shoots eaten raw and leaves used as cattle feed in folk practice

Climate Requirements: Tropical to subtropical; hardy tree tolerant of drought and low water availability; thrives in low-lying, deciduous, and wooded areas
Soil Type: Prefers well-drained sandy to loamy soils; tolerates poor and dry soils
Growth Rate: Moderate to fast growth; up to 15 m tall
Ecological Role: Provides shade and wind protection; improves soil fertility; acts as natural pest repellent in agriculture; supports biodiversity near temples and villages
Traditional Uses: Integral to Ayurveda and Unani medicine; used for malaria, diabetes, cardiovascular and skin diseases, antiulcer and antifungal remedies; all parts (root, bark, leaves, flowers, fruit, seed) used medicinally; neem oil used as pesticide and cosmetic; young shoots and flowers eaten during Ugadi and Gudi Padwa; sacred in Hindu rituals—leaves and flowers used in Mariamman festivals and for purification ceremonies

Climate Requirements: Tropical to subtropical; prefers warm, wet climates; cannot tolerate prolonged freezing; sensitive to salinity (dies above 5.5‰)
Soil Type: Aquatic, free-floating; grows best in nutrient-rich freshwater with neutral pH
Sun Light Needs: Prefers full sunlight but can survive in partial shade
Water Needs: Very high; thrives in flooded or waterlogged conditions
Growth Rate: Fast-growing aquatic fern; forms dense mats on still water
Ecological Role: Symbiotic relationship with nitrogen-fixing Anabaena cyanobacteria; improves soil fertility in paddy fields; provides habitat for aquatic organisms; can suppress mosquito breeding
Traditional Uses: Used as biofertilizer in rice cultivation due to nitrogen fixation; used as livestock and fish feed; considered symbolic in folklore for repelling mosquitoes (“mosquito fern” myth); occasionally cultivated as an ornamental aquatic plant

Climate Requirements: Warm tropical/subtropical; tolerant and hardy with low nutrient/water demands; occurs from sea level–900 m; found in open woods, shrublands, grasslands, disturbed sites, roadsides, beaches, and limestone rocks
Soil Type: Well-drained soils; grows on varied substrates including limestone
Water Needs: Average overall; water moderately in growing season; sparingly in winter
Ecological Role: Insect-pollinated; adaptable pioneer in disturbed areas; supports urban/roadside greening
Traditional Uses: Medicinal use in Ayurveda/Folk/Modern contexts; used for organ-specific disorders incl. cancer, diabetes, hypertension; also cultivated as an ornamental

Climate Requirements: Grows in cultivated fields, plains, gardens, kitchen gardens, shaded moist areas, and rocky cliffs in primary forests
Ecological Role: Provides ground cover in cultivated and natural habitats; aromatic rhizomes attract pollinators and aid soil aeration
Traditional Uses: Rhizomes used medicinally and as spice; contains curcumin with antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and antimicrobial properties; used in Ayurveda for treating pain, inflammation, infections, and systemic disorders; food spice in Indian cuisine

Climate Requirements: Grows in damp places; needs presence of other trees in vicinity
Ecological Role: Forms woody creepers; spreads rapidly forming thickets and smothering vegetation; considered a weed in many regions
Traditional Uses: Medicinal: used for rheumatism, scabies, asthma, skin complaints & ulcers, inflammation, cough; systems: Ayurveda, Folk Medicine; parts used: root, bark, flower.

Climate Requirements: Usually in aquatic environments and moist soils
Ecological Role: Often locally dominant; can form extensive stands

Traditional Uses: cultivated for medicinal, cosmetic, ornamental, religious use

Ecological Role: Spreading root system used to prevent soil erosion
Traditional Uses: Human consumption (edible flowers & fruits); medicinal (Ayurveda, Folk); religious use; wood/timber; seed oil for soap & candles; seed cake as organic fertilizer; explored for biofuel

Climate Requirements: Temporarily flooded habitats; shallow pools, river edges, canals, ditches, rice fields
Ecological Role: Often locally dominant; forms large, dense colonies in temporarily flooded places
Traditional Uses: Folk medicine (plant used); food use of sporophyte by natives of Andaman Islands

Climate Requirements: grows where rainfall is slightly seasonal
Water Needs: Doesn’t require a lot of water

Soil Type: Grows on soils from sedimentary & igneous rocks
Ecological Role: Contributes to biodiversity; protects soil; furnishes food & cover for wildlife
Traditional Uses: Ornamental hedge/topiary/bonsai; wood for small fine items; folk medicinal uses (joint pain, body aches, venereal disease, diarrhea, dysentery, wounds; abortion noted at high doses).

Climate Requirements: Warm season; thrives in shallow, permanent water bodies
Soil Type: Rooted in nutrient-rich mud/silt of ponds, lakes, slow rivers

Climate Requirements: Requires average rainfall; grows in regular soil
Traditional Uses: flowers studied for anti-skin cancer properties
